Dear Ms. Phillips:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 09/23/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and MISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 860-0787.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months
before placement or a new physical examination shall be
completed within 30 calendar days after placement.
One of eight open child records reviewed showed the child’s
medical due by 11/17/2021 was completed over four months
late on 4/1/2022.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One of six initial service plans reviewed was two days late.
R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404 (4).
Four of six initial service plans reviewed showed the
documentation for (c) was missing from the service plan.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
3

updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed
did not show documentation of an updated contract, which was
due in June 2022.
R400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
Two of five adoptive applicant records reviewed showed:
• One family’s 2/24/2022 and 5/19/2022 respective
evaluations (DHS-612) were not provided until 7/18/2022.
• A second family’s 5/11/2022(CWL- 3130) and
6/2/2022(DHS-612) evaluations were not provided until
8/8/2022.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
Nothing this inspection.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
4

community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the standard:
• One child’s record did not show documentation of an
FTM for the child’s 11/3/2021-12/8/2021 ISP. One was
completed after the period on 12/29/2021.
• A second child’s record did not show documentation of
an FTM for the child’s 8/27/2021-11/24/2021 or
11/25/2021-2/22/2022 USP.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021; Interim 2020.
FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, And Timeframes.
Supervisor Approval:
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
Three of 18 services plans reviewed were approved one day
late respectively.
Repeat Violation- Cited under 722-9 Renewal 2021.
5

FOM 722-8D Treatment plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Eleven of 18 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s 4/26/2022-5/25/2022 ISP treatment plan was
not signed by the caregiver until 7/19/2022. It was not
signed by the birth parents until 8/9/2022.
• A second child’s 4/20/2022-5/20/2022 USP treatment
plan was signed by the caregiver but not dated. It could
not be discerned if the treatment plan was signed timely.
• A third child’s 10/15/2021-11/10/2021 ISP treatment plan,
and 11/11/2021-1/31/2022 USP treatment plan were not
signed by the caregiver until 4/22/2022. Additionally, this
record did not show documentation of a 4/30/2022-
7/26/2022 USP treatment plan signed by the caregiver.
• A fourth child’s 11/3/2021-12/8/2021 ISP treatment plan
was signed by the caregiver and birth parents but not
dated. It could not be discerned if the parties signed the
treatment plan timely. Additionally, this child’s 3/9/2022-
6/3/2022 treatment plan was not signed by the caregiver
until 8/9/2022. Furthermore, this child’s12/9/2021-
2/8/2022 USP treatment plan was not signed by the birth
parents.
• A fifth child’s 8/27/2021-11/24/2021 and 11/25/2021-
2/22/2022 UPS treatment plans were signed by the
caregiver but not dated. It could not be discerned if these
treatment plans were signed timely.
• An independent living youth’s 1/19/2022-4/15/2022 USP
treatment plan was signed by the youth but not dated. It
could not be discerned if the youth signed the treatment
plan timely.
Repeat Violation- cited under 722-8C Renewal 2021; Interim
2020.
FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
6

MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change.
• Three days prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement
change.
• Within three business days of foster care or juvenile
justice program case closure
Three of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One child’s record showed the DHS-69 for the child’s
2/22/2022 case closure was not completed within three
business days. The DHS-69 was due by 2/25/2022 and
completed on 3/3/2022.
• A second child’s record did not show documentation of a
DHS-69 for the child’s 11/19/2021 placement with a legal
father.
• A third child’s record did not show documentation of a
DHS-69 for the child’s 12/20/2021 placement with the
birth parent.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021.
FOM 722-15 Discharge documents.
The caseworker must provide the following documents to the
child's legal parent/guardian, or to the youth if the youth is age
18 or older or has been legally emancipated, at the time of
closure:
• A certified copy of the child's birth certificate (retain a
copy in the case record).
• The child's social security card. Note: In cases where the
social security number has been verified and
documented per policy, the caseworker must make
efforts to obtain a social security card.
• Any available education records.
Three of eight closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation the parent was provided a copy of the child’s
birth certificate and social security card. Additionally, one of
these records did not show documentation the parent was
provided an education record for the child.
7

FOM 801-3 Medical passport.
Updated Medical Passport:
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward; Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement;
and at reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each
placement and quarterly.
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• Three child records did not show documentation that the
medical passport was provided to the caregiver at initial
placement. Additionally, one of these records did not
show documentation of a July 2022 quarterly medical
passport for the child.
• A fourth child’s record did not show documentation of a
March or June 2022 quarterly medical passport for the
child.
Repeat Violation – Cited under MISEP 6.49- Renewal 2021.
FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental Need of
Children under supervision of MDHHS.
All children entering foster care are required to have a mental
health screening within 30 days of removal. The screening
instrument must be completed by a person who knows the child
best, before the child's Early Periodic, Screening, Diagnostic,
and Treatment (EPSTD)/well child exam.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the
child’s trauma screening was completed on 6/2/2022, more than
30 days after the child’s 4/21/2022 date of placement.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12326((1)(a)(c)(d) Borrowed home.

Additionally, its endorsement of the certifying agency’s evaluation and
reevaluation shall be consistently dated and legible.

The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related

.
The agency completed tools, trainings and items identified in its corrective action
plan. It also made significant gains related to compliance with prior cited rules. The
agency was not totally successful with compliance with of all aspects of the corrective
9

action plan, in that it received six repeat violations, as indicated in this report.
DCWL ANAYLST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
The agency received two safety alerts:
Safety Alert #1, dated 9/13/2022:
Concern:
The home does not have a working smoke detector. There was one smoke detector
observed in the home. It was not placed properly on a wall or ceiling. It was beeping
during the visit.
Resolution:
The home now has a working smoke detector located on the first floor between the
bedrooms; and it is installed properly on the hallway ceiling. The working smoke
detector was verified by the licensing worker; the caregiver sent a video of the working
smoke detector to the agency on 9/14/22.
Safety Alert #2, dated 9/26/2022:
This is a pending alert that the agency has not resolved. An addendum to this report
will be issued when the alert is resolved.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator’s report dated 8/30/2022 was received. Areas reviewed as a
part of that report related to the citations listed earlier in this report.
Interviews
The chief administrator and four managerial staff participated in the entrance
conference and exit conference. A review and discussion around the agency’s last
inspection’s corrective action plan, staff and policy changes since that last inspection,
and the agency’s review of its current status/program functioning, were the focus of the
entrance conference. Two foster care staff, one licensing staff and one adoption staff
were interviewed, as were three adoptive parents during this inspection.
Rule and policy violations found this inspection, the two safety alerts, and themes that
were revealed from staff and adoptive parents interviews were the focus of the exit
conference. The DCWL Analyst was in attendance at the exit conference. She shared
information related to the safety alerts, and her contact with foster parents and
unlicensed relatives she visited this inspection.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
